quote: Have a seat, Jake.  Dinner's almost    ready.
Let me guess, you convinced the    Peljenites to exchange ambassadors    with the Federation.
How did you know that?
You're cooking chicken paprikash.       You only cook Hungarian food when    you're in a really good mood.
I always said you were a smart kid.
Runs in the family.
You know, I've got some good news,    too.       Captain Yates is back on the station.
Kasidy Yates.  The freighter captain    I told you about.
The one you want me to meet?
I really think you'd like her.
Maybe I'll run into her.
I could invite her over for dinner.     How about tomorrow night?
You're not going to give up on this,    are you?
Is nineteen hundred hours okay?
I think we're getting a little ahead    of ourselves here.    (before Jake can     protest)   Look, Jake I know you want me to    meet her, and I will.  Just let me    handle it my way.
You're going to like her, Dad.
You never know.
The place is packed.  Where's Nog?
I gave him the night off.
You what?
He's studying.  For his Starfleet    exams.       He's a very dedicated student.
He's a disgrace to his family... and    to Ferengi everywhere.  He should be    here, helping us earn profit, not in    his room, learning how to be more    like a...       Human.
He doesn't want to be Human, Brother.     He just wants to join Starfleet.
It's the same thing.

Don't you see?  This is how it begins.     All it takes is for one impressionable    youngster to join Starfleet, and the    next thing you know, a whole    generation of Ferengi will be quoting    the Prime Directive and abandoning    the pursuit of latinum.       It's the end of Ferengi civilization    as we know it and it's all your fault.
Relax, brother.  Nog isn't going to    destroy the Ferengi way of life.  He    just wants a job with better hours.
You must be Quark.
That's me.  What can I do for you?
Brunt.  F.C.A.
The Ferengi Commerce Authority.
A Writ of Accountability.
We're in trouble.
All right, everyone.  The bar is    closed.  Everybody out.  Go, go, go.     Now, now, now.
So, how do you get to be an F.C.A.    liquidator anyway?
(concentrating on his     work)   Hard work, bribes, and sucking up to    the boss.  Just like any other job.
You've had a very profitable year,    haven't you?
(simultaneous   (simultaneous    with Rom)    with Quark)  No.     Yes.
(simultaneous   (simultaneous    with Rom)    with Quark)  Yes.     No.
What we mean is, it's been a    profitable year, but not as    profitable as others.  You know    how it is...
... with the Dominion and the Maquis,    people just don't like to travel    anymore.
Are these all your assets?
Down to the last slip of latinum.
You realize that concealing financial    information from the F.C.A. can result    in severe fines?
I would never dream of trying to    hide anything from the F.C.A.
We'll see.
Could I look over those figures again?
Wait a minute.  That can't be right.
Rom, you forgot to include the profit    figures for the tulaberry wine    franchise.
But you told me...
Go get them.  Now.
Yes, Brother.
You'll have to excuse Rom.  He means    well, but he can be a lobeless idiot    sometimes.
Please provide a dermal imprint for    F.C.A. records.
You haven't even told me what I'm    being charged with.
No.  I haven't.
Oh... How rude of me.
For your trouble.
You're charged with violating the    Ferengi Trade Bylaws... subsection    one thousand twenty-seven, paragraph    three.
Subsection one thousand twenty-seven,    paragraph three?  I'm not sure I'm    familiar with that one.
In that case what you need is a copy    of the Bylaws.
Which you just happen to have.
Subsection one thousand twenty-seven,    paragraph three.  Improper supervision    of a family member?
That's correct.
I knew it.  This is about Nog, isn't    it?
Nog?  Nog hasn't done anything wrong.

You see what I'm up against?  I know    that as the eldest male I'm    responsible for the actions taken by    members of my family.  But what am I    supposed to do?  I told Rom not to    let the boy apply to Starfleet    Academy, but he wouldn't lift a finger    to stop him.
Your nephew is going to Starfleet    Academy?
Did I say that?
You're clearly incapable of    controlling your family.
If this isn't about Nog, then why    have I been served with a Writ?
You are being held accountable for    the criminal activities of one Ishka,    daughter of Adred, wife of Keldar.
Ishka?  You mean...       Our mother?       What's she done?
She's charged with... earning profit.
Earning profit?  Our Moogie?

Odo, I'm holding you personally    responsible for the safety of my bar    and personal possessions for as long    as I'm off the station.       And make sure my thieving brother    doesn't touch anything.
Going somewhere?
Back to the homeworld to take care    of some business.
A little trouble with the F.C.A.?
How'd you know?
I won't be gone long.  All I have to    do is get my mother to confess to    her crimes and I'll be on the next    transport back to the station.
Your mother?  What's she done?
It doesn't matter.  The important    thing is I'm required by law to get    her to admit her wrongdoing, make    reparations and reveal her    accomplices.  And that's what I'm    going to do.
Assuming she cooperates.
She'd better.  I have no intention    of spending my latinum to make    restitution for her crimes.  I'll    wring that confession out of her if    I have to.
(surprised at Quark's     vehemence)   This is your mother you're talking    about.
Don't remind me.
Chief O'Brien wants to know when you    can stop by and inspect the new    runabout.
I'll be available at fourteen hundred    hours.  And tell him I want to name    it the Rubicon.
The Rubicon it is.       You know, at the rate we go through    runabouts, it's a good thing the    Earth has a lot of rivers.
So, have you met her yet?
Met who?
Captain Yates.
How do you know about her?
Jake introduced us.       So are you going to ask her to dinner?
I'm considering it.       What did you think of her?
Let me put it this way, if I was    Curzon, I'd have stolen her from you    already.
Which is one of the reasons I'm glad    you're not Curzon anymore.
Brother, wait.
I'm coming with you.
No, you're not.
Yes, I am.
What did I tell you about    contradicting me?
You told me not to do it.
That's right.  So you're going to    stay here and watch over the bar    while I'm gone.
No, I'm not.  The bar is closed.     There's no reason why I can't come    along.
You want a reason?  I'll give you a    reason.  I don't want you to.  And    you know why?  Because you'll just    take her side.
You mean Moogie?
Yes, I mean Moogie.  And stop calling    her by that infantile nickname.
But she likes it.
Well I don't.
Well she does.
You see?  You always take her side.
Somebody has to.  After all, she is    our mother.       Now I'm coming with you.  And that's    final.
Fine.  Come if you want.  Just    remember one thing... this is between    Moogie... , I mean Mother, and me.     So if you know what's good for you,    you'll stay out of the way.
I don't think so.

(a traditional     welcoming ceremony)   Welcome to our home.  Please place    your imprint on the legal waivers    and deposit your admission fee in    the basket by the door.  Remember,    my house is my house...
(a traditional     response, handing     back the towel)   As are its contents.
It's good to be back, isn't it    Brother?
Now that you mention it... no.
But you haven't been here in twenty    years.
Mother certainly has been... acquiring    quite a few new things.
Doubtlessly with the generous stipend    you give her.
Look, Brother.  The latinum    tooth-sharpener I used when we were    children.
All I had was a cheap wooden    chewstick.
Excuse me for interrupting, but we    have business to attend to.
As a registered liquidator, it is my    duty to present a formal list of the    infractions committed by your mother.     You have three days to obtain an    admission of guilt from the accused.
Three days?  Is that all?

If you are not able to obtain a    confession, your mother will be placed    in indentured servitude and you will    be required to make restitution for    her crimes.  Do you understand    everything I've said to you?
He understands, all right.
Not that it matters.  I'm not    confessing to anything.
Moogie!
It's good to see you, Son.  You look    well.
And you look...       Dressed.
Your mother is wearing clothes.
Mother, get undressed this instant.
Hello, Quark.       You haven't changed a bit.
Perhaps I should leave.
Perhaps you should.
Was she addressing me?
No no no, not at all.
Of course I was.  This is my home    and I'll speak to whomever I want.
But Moogie, he's a stranger, and    you're a female.
It's all right, Rom.  I know what    I'm doing.
Perhaps you do, but I will not stand    here and be spoken to by a female.
You have three days to get your house    in order.
Now see what you've done.
Quark, you're upsetting your brother.
He's not the only one who's upset.     Not that anyone cares how I feel.
That's not true...       I care.
Then imprint this... and take off    those clothes.
I'm not doing anything of the kind.
Yes you are.  You're going to make a    full confession, so I can go back to    my bar and pretend none of this ever    happened.
You mean we're leaving so soon?
Rom, this is your home.  You can    stay as long as you like.       Or leave whenever you like.  It's up    to you.
Same old Moogie.
Are you sure this is absolutely    necessary?
Well I don't know if I would call it    "necessary."
Constable, there's no telling how    long Quark will be gone.  Besides,    all we want is our dartboard.
Can't you just replicate another    one?
We could...

But we're not going to.  That's our    dartboard and we want it back.  If    Quark was going to run off, you think    the least he could do is give us a    little warning so we could retrieve    our property.
It's the principle of the thing.
Well getting it back might not be as    simple as you think.
This is one of Rom's special security    locks.  I've never seen anything so    convoluted.
Is there a problem, gentlemen?
It seems Quark locked some of Chief    O'Brien and Doctor Bashir's personal    property inside his bar.
Let me guess... your lucky dartboard?
We never said it was a "lucky"    dartboard.
We're just used to playing on it,    that's all.
A little defensive, aren't they?
Hmm, a tripartite microsealing    mechanism.  That's going to take a    while to get through.    (but it's not his     problem)   If you want any suggestions, I'll be    in cargo bay...
Four.
Seven.
Oh, I just thought...
Thought what?
Thought you were going to visit that    freighter captain.
You know... Jake's friend.
How do you two know about that?
The chief told me.
Captain Yates seems like a very    capable woman.
(trying to be one of     the guys)   Not bad looking either...       Or so I've been told.
Exactly how many people has Jake    talked to about this woman?
Everyone.
Tube grubs, extra juicy, just the    way you like them.
What's wrong, Brother?  Aren't you    hungry?
What are you doing?
Serving dinner.
That's mother's job.
She's not feeling well.
Not feeling well?  Wait a minute,    that's not bad.  We could say she's    having emotional problems.  We might    even be able to get the F.C.A. to    drop the charges in light of her    illness.
Actually, all she has is a slight    rash.  Her skin's still a little    sensitive to clothing.
That's hardly an excuse not to serve    her sons dinner.
Look at this... she hasn't even    softened these grubs for us.
You know Moogie.  She never liked to    chew our food for us.
Not even when we were children.
She always had her own way of doing    things.

Remember how the other children used    to tease us about her.       "Your mother won't chew your food.     Your mother talks to strangers."    It's like she went out of her way to    embarrass us.  Not to mention Father.       I remember there were nights when I    would find him sitting, slumped in    that chair.  He'd say to me, "Quark,    I don't know what I'm going to do    about that female." No wonder he    never made much profit.  He was too    busy worrying about her.
I thought Father did all right.

He could've done a lot better, if    she'd just behaved herself... showed    him the respect he deserved.       Well, she may have dragged Father    down, but she's not doing the same    to me.  It's time someone put her in    her place.
Have anyone in mind for the job?
Mmm, dank and musty.
I hand picked them from the cellar.
Mother, we need to talk.
We can talk later.  These tube grubs    are getting warm.
The tube grubs can wait.  You've had    your fun, you've proved you could    earn a little profit, but now it's    over.
Forget it, Quark.       I'm not imprinting any confession.
Why not?  Imprinting the confession    doesn't take away your... achievement.     Just admit to what you did and tell    the F.C.A. the name of any male who    might've helped you.
What exactly did she do, Brother?
Never mind what she did.
Why don't you tell him?  Or would    you prefer I did?
All right.       She took part of the monthly stipend    that I send her and invested it in    a Hupyrian beetle farm.
High quality beetles.  The best.
Really?  How much did you make,    Moogie?
Three bars of gold-pressed latinum.
Three bars of latinum?       Isn't the F.C.A. overreacting a    little?
It doesn't matter if it's one slip    or a hundred thousand bars, females    are not allowed to earn profit.
Why not?
Because it's the law.  And without    law, society would descend into chaos.
If you ask me, our society could use    a little chaos...
Not if I have anything to say about    it.
Gee, I wish Father were alive.
Then it'd be just like old times...    sitting around the family table,    eating tube grubs, discussing    important issues of the day.
Mother, I know you're not like other    females.  You like to think about    things... you have opinions...
Is that a compliment, or an    accusation?
It's a fact.  But what's also a fact,    is that if you don't imprint this    confession, you'll be sold into    indentured servitude, and I'll be    forced to make restitution.
But Brother, it's only three bars of    latinum.

And I'm not going to allow those    three bars to destroy our family.       If our disgrace is made known, do    you think we could ever do business    with another Ferengi again?  I    wouldn't do business with me.
Mother, please, for our family's    reputation, for your sons' financial    future, please, imprint the    confession.
I can't.  I wish you could understand,    Quark.
I understand perfectly.  You're a    selfish female, who never cared about    this family, about Father, or about    me.
Rom, could you pass the millipede    sauce?
I see you haven't changed your    bedroom, Moogie.  It's still very...    traditional.
I keep it this way to remind myself    how idiotic Ferengi tradition can be    when it comes to females.
Oh.
Rom, is something wrong?
Wrong... No... Not really... except...       Your clothes.
Would you feel more comfortable if I    took them off?
Well, maybe... just a little.
All right... if it makes you feel    better.  But only for you.
Better?
Much.       You know, Moogie, it really would    mean a lot to Quark if you imprinted    that confession.
He's made that quite clear.
I know he can be headstrong and    overbearing, not to mention mean...    and insulting... and rude... but    he's not all bad.  He works hard.     You should see the bar.  It's    thriving.
I'd like to.  But Ferengi tradition    doesn't allow females to travel.
Quark doesn't make the rules.
He just lives by them.
Like a good Ferengi.
Like an unenlightened Ferengi.
Moogie, can't you give back the three    bars of latinum?  If you don't, you're    going to destroy everything Quark's    worked for.
You always were a good boy.  I don't    think Quark knows how lucky he is to    have a brother as loyal as you.
He knows.  He just doesn't like    showing it.
This isn't about money, Rom.  Quark    has always been very generous with    my stipend.  I have more than enough    to live on.
If it's not about money, then what    is it about?

It's about pride.  And knowing that    I'm just as capable of earning profit    as any male.  Don't you see, if I    imprint that confession, it'll mean    admitting what I did was wrong.  And    I'm not going to do that.  I'd rather    be sold into servitude.
But what about Quark?
He's a smart boy.  He can take care    of himself.
Now that's enough about your brother.     Let me see those teeth.
My teeth?  Why?
They're looking a little dull.       Why don't you sit down.  I'll sharpen    them for you.
Aw, Moogie... You're the best.
Pardshay, don't be an idiot.  Go get    an anti-grav sled before you hurt    yourself.
Why don't you just beam it to your    cargo hold?
I wish I could.  But it's unstable    biomatter.
The transporter should still be able    to handle it, as long as you adjust    the phase transition inhibitor.
Provided I had a Mark Seven    Transporter.
You're still using a Mark Six?
A Mark Five.
A Mark Five?  I thought they stopped    making those...
Fifteen years ago.  But when you're    working for the Petarians, you have    to make do with what they give you.
Let me guess... Commander Sisko.
Benjamin.
Kasidy... Kasidy Yates.
I know.
My son's told me a lot about you.
I think Jake fancies himself something    of a matchmaker.
He means well.  But he does get a    little too enthusiastic now and then.
Damn, that sounded like the inertium    ore.       I'd better see what's going on.
I'll give you a hand.
I can take care of it.
Of course.  Sorry about Jake.
How about coffee?  Tomorrow evening...    say eighteen hundred hours?
Sounds good.
Then I'll see you tomorrow.
There's nothing like sleeping in    your old room.
scene: 20   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - MORNING

quote: So, how was your night?
scene: 20   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - MORNING

quote: Mother's been busy.
scene: 20   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - MORNING

quote: Really, I didn't even know she was    up yet.
scene: 20   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - MORNING

quote: I mean she's been busy.  I've been    doing some checking.  This isn't    about three bars of latinum.
scene: 20   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - MORNING

quote: You mean she earned more?
scene: 20   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - MORNING

quote: A lot more.  So much that I haven't    even been able to track it all down.
scene: 20   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - MORNING

quote: It means Moogie's got the lobes for    business.
scene: 20   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - MORNING

quote: Even if I sold everything I had I    couldn't come close to paying back    what she's earned.       I'm ruined.
scene: 20   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - MORNING

quote: Coffee?  That's it?  All you're going    to have is coffee?
Well, I was thinking of having an    icoberry tart.
You know what I mean.  A cup of coffee    doesn't give you a lot of time to    get to know someone.
We're not even sure we want to get    to know each other.
I haven't heard any news, but I'm    sure when Quark gets back you'll be    the first to know.
So what are you two going to talk    about?
I have no idea.
Well, you should think about it,    rehearse a few clever things to say,    come up with a couple of good stories    to catch her interest...
Jake, this isn't exactly my first    date.
It's your first date in a long time.
You're just going to have to have a    little faith in the old man.
I guess you'll do fine.       So what are you going to wear?
This.
Your uniform?
Brother, is everything all right?

I'm so proud of you, Quark.    (still no response     from Quark)   I mean other people in your situation    might overreact and lose their temper,    make a bad situation worse.  But not    my brother.  You're too smart for    that.  You're going to sit there and    study the problem, and then come up    with a clear, simple solution.
I already have.
You see, I told you.       What is it?
I'm going to kill her.
Moogie?
A-ha.  Caught you.  Give me that.
Give you what?
That PADD you just hid under the    mattress.
It's a letter to your cousin Stol.
A likely story.
I knew it.  You were trying to hide    more profits.  Well it won't work.     I know all about your little financial    empire.
It's not so little.
Then you admit it?
Brother, calm down.  I'm sure Moogie    has a perfectly good explanation for    what she's done.       Don't you, Moogie?
Since when does a Ferengi have to    make excuses for earning profit?
You're a female.
And when it comes to profit, this    female is a better Ferengi than you'll    ever be.
You expect me to believe you did all    this on your own?  You had help,    admit it.  Tell me his name.  I'll    see to it that the F.C.A. hangs him    by his lobes in the Sacred    Marketplace.
Quark, sometimes you can be so thick-   headed.
Now, Moogie, there's no need to be    insulting.
Of course there is.  Insults are the    only thing he understands.  He's so    blind with jealousy, he can't even    think straight.
Me?  Jealous of you?  Hah.
You're just like your father.
Why would Father be jealous of you?
Because he knew I had the lobes for    business and he didn't.  I tried to    help him, give him financial advice,    but he wouldn't listen to me.  Because    I was a female.
What other reason did he need?     Females don't belong in business.
Give me one reason why not.
Because it's wrong.
You're going to have to do better    than that.
No I'm not.  It's the law.  That was    good enough for Father, and it's    good enough for me.
A lot of things were good enough for    your father.  He was a lobeless    failure... and if you're not careful,    you're going to end up just like    him.
That does it.
Brother, where are you going?
To the F.C.A.       Let's see what they have to say about    your...       "Financial Empire."
Brother, wait.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Out of my way, Rom.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: No.  I'm not going to let you hurt    Mother.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: She's no mother of mine.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Why?  Because of what she said about    Father?  Did it ever occur to you    that she might be right?
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: How dare you take her side against    Father?
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Don't tell me about Father.  I knew    him a lot better than you did.  You    ran off as soon as you reached the    Age of Ascension.  But I stayed here    for ten more years.  And you know    what I learned in those ten years?     I learned that Father was no financial    genius.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Take that back.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: It's the truth.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: He went from one bad deal to the    next, one failure after another.  He    couldn't hold onto latinum if you    sewed it into his pants.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: That does it.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Quark.  Rom.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: That's enough.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Let him go.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: But Moogie...
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Stop it, both of you.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: If your brother wants to go to the    F.C.A., let him.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: But you'll get in trouble.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: I'll worry about that.
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: Go on.  What are you waiting for?
scene: 24   INT. ISHKA'S HOUSE - MAIN ROOM - CONTINUOUS

quote: That's the steepest forty flights of    stairs I've ever climbed.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: Seven slips of latinum to use the    elevator.  Talk about inflation.       Refined dilithium down ten percent?
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: The name's Quark.  I'm here to see    Liquidator Brunt.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: Oh, of course.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: And two more.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: For use of the financial data net.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: But I barely looked at it.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: Which is why I'm only charging you    two slips.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: I'll tell Liquidator Brunt that you're    here.  Have a seat.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: How much?
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: Three slips.  A bargain.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: I'll stand.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: That'll be one slip.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: (getting back into     the swing of things)   I'll give you two for the chair.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: If you're here to deliver an imprinted    confession, you can leave it with    me.  I'll see that Liquidator Brunt    gets it.  For a nominal handling    charge.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: Tell Brunt I need to talk to him    now.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: I have information that could shake    the very foundation of the Ferengi    Alliance.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: Brother.  Wait.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: I have to sit down.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: That'll be three slips of latinum.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: Brother, can you loan me...
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: Yeah, yeah.  Here.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: Now what do you want?
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: (finally catching his     breath)   I have a message from Moogie.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: There's nothing she could say that    would interest me.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: She'll share it with you.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: What was that?
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: Her profits.  Fifty-fifty.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: Tell Brunt I'll talk to him later.       Come on.  Let's try out that elevator.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: But it's so expensive.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: I can afford it.
scene: 28   INT. TOWER OF COMMERCE - BRUNT'S ANTECHAMBER (VPB)

quote: Mother, I want to apologize for all    the terrible things I said.  I was    angry, and I got carried away.  I'm    sorry.
Apology accepted.  I'm just glad    that Rom was able to catch you before    you made a horrible mistake.
It would've been a shame to waste    all that profit.
I'm glad we agree.
So, just how much latinum have you    made?
Does it matter?
I only want to make sure everything    is divided fairly.
Divided?
Fifty-fifty.  Just like you said.
I never said that.       You said he'd let me keep all the    profit for myself.
I said no such thing.
So I lied to both of you.  I had no    choice.  It was the only way to get    the two of you talking again.
There's nothing to say.
Don't get your lobes caught in the    door on your way out.

That's enough bickering.  You're    both acting like children.  I will    not stand by and let this family    fall apart.       Quark, you should be ashamed of    yourself.  I've seen you treat    Cardassians with more respect than    you show your own mother.       And Moogie, if Quark can uncover    your hidden investments, eventually    the F.C.A. will too.  And all that    profit will be lost.  Think about    that for a moment.
Now neither of you is going to leave    this room until you've settled things.     Is that clear?
And no shouting.  I'm going to take    a nap.
He's a sweet boy.
That's easy for you to say.  He    doesn't live next door to you.
You're too hard on him.  You always    have been.
I had to be.  You were always too    easy on him.  Maybe if you'd pushed    him a little harder, he would've    amounted to something.
I doubt it.  When it comes to    business, he takes after your father.
You enjoy insulting Father, don't    you?
I'm not insulting anyone; I'm just    being honest.  Rom's a lot like his    father...       And I suppose, you're a lot like me.
I never knew you felt that way.
Your father might've bought you your    first copy of the Rules of    Acquisition, but who helped you    memorize them?
You did.
I don't think I've ever been prouder    than the first time you made it    through all two hundred and eighty-   five rules without a mistake.
Rom knows them just as well as I do.

But you understand them.  Rom never    did.  And neither did your father.       But even if Keldar didn't know the    first thing about profit, he knew    everything about family.  He was a    good husband and a wonderful father.     And I loved him for that.  The same    way I love Rom...       And the same way I love you.
You mean that?
Yes, I suppose I do.       If it'll make you happy, I'll give    back the money.
You'll imprint the confession?
You're my son, Quark.  How can I    refuse you?
You don't know how much this means    to me.
I know exactly how much it means to    you.
Oh, Moogie.  I love you.
There's no place like New Orleans    for simple pleasures... good food,    good music...
Sounds like a great place to grow    up.
The best.       Can I get you another raktajino?
No, I'm fine.
You seem a little... preoccupied.
It's just... when we made our plans    I forgot I had a... previous    engagement.
I see.
It's not what you think.  It's kind    of a family obligation.  You see, my    youngest brother's a colonist on    Cestus Three.
That's on the other side of the    Federation.
It's so far away, it takes two weeks    for a subspace transmission to get    here and I'm expecting one tonight.     I promised my brother I'd listen to    it as it came in.
I hope nothing's wrong.
Not unless he hurt himself again.     Last time he tore some ligaments in    his knee.
How'd that happen?
(doesn't know how to     explain)   He was doing something called "sliding    into second."
"Sliding into second?"  That sounds    like baseball.
You know about baseball?
It's my favorite sport.  But no one's    played it in two hundred years.
Well they're playing it on Cestus    Three... at least they have been for    the past six months.
I had no idea.  That's fantastic.     How many teams are there?
Six.  But they're trying to organize    a couple more.       I didn't know you liked baseball.
I didn't know anyone liked baseball,    except for Jake and me.

Look, this transmission I mentioned,    it's an audio recording of a game    between my brother's team, the Pike    City Pioneers and the Cestus Comets.     If you'd like you're welcome to listen    to it with me.
I'd love to.
So does your brother's league use    the designated hitter rule?
No.  They thought about it, but    decided against it.
Wood bats or polyduranide?
Wood, of course.
Could they use a right handed pitcher?
There.  I hope that's satisfactory.
Everything seems to be in order.
I'm glad we can finally put an end    to this matter.       And I certainly hope you've learned    your lesson.
And what would that be?
She's speaking to me again.
No she wasn't.
She was speaking to me.       Now what were you saying about a    lesson?
The lesson is... No one can outsmart    the F.C.A.
I think she's certainly learned that.     Right, Mother?
Your mother's confession will serve    as a warning to females all over the    Alliance.
Oh, I don't think anyone has to know    about this.
After all, what would people say if    they knew a female had made that    much latinum?
I shudder to think.
Goodbye.  I sincerely hope I never    see any of you again.
The feeling is mutual.
I thought he'd never leave.
Mother, must you?
Quark, I've just given up a sizable    fortune.  I'm in no mood for your    nagging.
You're absolutely right.  If you    want to wear clothes, go ahead...    What do I care?  I'm leaving anyway.
So soon?
I have to reopen the bar.  It's    supporting all of us now.
You know you could call your mother    every once in a while.  Maybe even    visit.
I will... I promise.
Let's go, Rom.
I'll be along in a moment, Brother.
I'm glad to see you two are finally    getting along.
I think things will be a lot better    between us from now on.
As long as he doesn't find out you    only gave the F.C.A. a third of your    profits.
If you ask me, a third was too much.     But it's my own fault for not hiding    it better.
You sure the F.C.A. won't find the    rest?
I've got it so well hidden, I'll be    lucky if I can find it.
Moogie...
Now don't start crying, Rom.  You'll    have me doing it.  Go on.  Quark's    waiting for you.
And take care of your brother.  I    worry about that boy.
